docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, plans to shine a light Thursday on the particular problems that women face with health insurance. Ms. Sebelius will join a round-table discussion in Portland, Me., with Representative Chellie Pingree, a Maine Democrat, and officials of AARP and the Maine Women's Lobby. Women who are insured through their employers tend to be protected by federal laws that bar sex discrimination. But those who buy insurance in the individual market face a variety of problems.
docs.abstract: Secretary of Health and Human Services Kathleen Sebelius will join round-table discussion in Portland, Maine, that will focus on women's health-insurance problems; panel will address various issues including gender rating, practice allowed by some states in which insurers can charge women of childbearing age more than men; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, plans to shine a light Thursday on the particular problems that women face with health insurance. Ms. Sebelius will join a round-table discussion in Portland, Me., with Representative...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some small-business owners have a new health care hero in Des Moines: Representative Leonard L. Boswell, right, a Blue Dog Democrat who represents a district in central Iowa. Des Moines members of a national group called the Main Street Alliance are celebrating Mr. Boswell's recent decision to come out in unambiguous support of a government-run ''public option'' for health insurance. The alliance is a network of small-business groups that back a health care overhaul along the lines supported by many Democrats.
docs.abstract: Rep Leonard L Boswell, Blue Dog Democrat who represents district in central Iowa, has emerged as health-care hero for some small-business owners; Des Moines members of small-business group called Main Street Alliance are celebrating Boswell's decision to come out in unambiguous support of government-run public option for health insurance; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Some small-business owners  have a new health care hero in Des Moines: Representative Leonard L. Boswell, right, a Blue Dog Democrat who represents a district in central Iowa.      Des Moines members of a national group called the Main Street...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people around the country say they fear government involvement in health care. But a new analysis of Gallup Poll data has found little difference in the way Americans on private health insurance plans rate their care, compared with people insured through the government Medicaid or Medicare programs. In either case, at least 7 in 10 Americans rated their insurance plan's coverage positively. And more than 8 in 10 usually give positive ratings to their plan's quality. Those figures remained consistent over the six years from 2003 through 2008.
docs.abstract: New analysis of Gallup Poll data finds that Americans in private health insurance plans and those covered by Medicare or Medicaid have similar feelings about their health care; at least 70 percent of people in both groups gave positive ratings to their insurance plan's coverage; more than 80 percent gave positive ratings to their plan's quality (M)
docs.snippet: Many people around the country say they fear government involvement in health care. But a new analysis of Gallup Poll data has found little difference in the way Americans on private health insurance plans rate their care, compared with people...

docs.lead_paragraph: My Thursday column notes that health reform may well be torpedoed by the visceral American suspicion of government programs. But I note that in fact there are a number of areas where we rely on single-payer systems (albeit at a local level) -- from police to fire. The only area where we're different than other countries is that they also have universal health care, while we don't.

headline.main: Public fire, police, libraries, schools - but not health care?

docs.abstract: The government manages to do a few things right. Health care is one of them.
docs.snippet: The government manages to do a few things right. Health care is one of them.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a memoir being published posthumously, Senator Edward M. Kennedy talks remorsefully about the car accident that claimed the life of Mary Jo Kopechne - a turn of events many consider a chief reason that he was never able to mount a successful bid for the presidency.

headline.main: Kennedy Memoir Talks of Chappaquiddick, J.F.K. and Other Presidents

docs.abstract: "True Compass," the memoir of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, is scheduled to be available later this month.
docs.snippet: "True Compass," the memoir of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy, is scheduled to be available later this month.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's time to pour one out for the public option.
docs.abstract: The White House seems to be retreating in this battle in the health care reform war.
docs.snippet: The White House seems to be retreating in this battle in the health care reform war.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's one of the lessons from the Massachusetts health care overhaul: the problem is not just the uninsured.

headline.main: Kaiser Study Finds Shortcomings in Massachusetts Insurance Programs

docs.abstract: A study of the Massachusetts health care overhaul indicates that the state's programs do not necessarily help people who have access to employer-provided insurance that may be too expensive for them.
docs.snippet: A study of the Massachusetts health care overhaul indicates that the state's programs do not necessarily help people who have access to employer-provided insurance that may be too expensive for them.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Main Street Alliance is a nascent national network of state small-business groups that back a health care overhaul along the lines of that supported by many Democrats. As the "You're the Boss" blog reports, in Des Moines, alliance members are celebrating the position of Representative Leonard L. Boswell, a Blue Dog Democrat who represents a swath of central Iowa. Mr. Boswell has come out in unambiguous support for a government-run "public option" for health insurance. Read all about it.

headline.main: Small Businesses in Iowa Celebrate Democrat's Support for 'Public Option'

docs.abstract: In Des Moines, members of a small-business alliance are celebrating the health care position of Representative Leonard L. Boswell, a Blue Dog Democrat who represents a swath of central Iowa. He supports a government-run "public option."
docs.snippet: In Des Moines, members of a small-business alliance are celebrating the health care position of Representative Leonard L. Boswell, a Blue Dog Democrat who represents a swath of central Iowa. He supports a government-run "public option."

docs.lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, you had a really interesting column about President Obama's slide in the polls on Tuesday, with a nice vacation's-over-back-to-work theme. So I'd like to talk about that.

headline.main: Who's to Blame on Health Care Reform?

docs.abstract: The fault in this mess is shared by Republicans, Democrats and the public.
docs.snippet: The fault in this mess is shared by Republicans, Democrats and the public.

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS AND GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: Marina, in Eugene, Ore., asks the following, in response to my column this morning:

headline.main: Reader Response: Health Care Reform in Steps

docs.abstract: Question: Is the United States the only rich country with for-profit insurers? Answer: Neen. (Or so the online English-Dutch translator tells us.)
